IQ is an indication of the mechanical efficiency of the brain and does not mean one necessarily will make good or bad decisions in life. Video game performance therefore correlates with IQ. As I'm fairly stupid, naturally, my performance in this video game is very mediocre. After hundreds of matches, my average score and position on the leaderboard has settled in the 3rd, 4th, & 5th place range and there's next to nothing I can do about it. Sometimes I get 1st, or get to play as the special MVP characters and it's interesting for a moment, but I'm aware that the rest of my team sucks when it happens. Queuing for a match has now become for me like the way boomers paw at slot machines. They want to win big, but really, they're just getting little dopamine hits from the bright colors and funny sounds. It can be said that I'm so simple-minded that I can be satisfied with pretending to swing a sword around in the virtual world for hours and I couldn't argue, since this is the way I just behaved for an entire month.  
It is not possible for man to avert that which God has decreed shall happen, but I am constrained by the path of least resistance; to do as the dopamine-spam-machine bids. Verily 'tis the sorest of all human ills, to abound in knowledge and yet have no power over action.

Chivalry 2 is a first-person multiplayer melee combat game developed by Torn Banner Studios and published by Tripwire Presents.

The gameplay centers on large-scale medieval battles where players fight with swords, axes, spears, bows, and other period weapons. Matches feature up to 64 players across sprawling maps with objectives like castle sieges, town raids, and open-field skirmishes.

Combat is physics-based and skill-driven. Players can slash, stab, block, feint, or parry attacks, and timing is critical. The system rewards precision and awareness rather than button-mashing, but it maintains accessibility for newcomers through intuitive controls.

The tone balances gritty realism with chaotic humor. Limbs fly, soldiers shout exaggerated battle cries, and the combat feels both brutal and absurd. This mix gives the game personality and keeps large fights entertaining rather than grim.

Visually, Chivalry 2 runs on Unreal Engine 4 and delivers detailed environments, realistic armor models, and strong lighting effects. The scale of battles is impressive, with hundreds of characters and dynamic action unfolding simultaneously.

Sound design is excellent. The clash of steel, explosions, and screams create an immersive battlefield soundscape. Music builds intensity during pushes and retreats, complementing the pacing of each match.

Overall, Chivalry 2 refines and expands the foundation of the first game, offering smoother combat, larger battles, and better performance. It captures the chaos, intensity, and absurd glory of medieval warfare better than any competitor in its genre.

Overall, I recommend the game. It's a really fun medieval combat game.
But I may only recommend it if you haven't played Chivalry 1, because as a Chivalry 1 fan, I feel as though this game is one step forward and one step back. Here's why.

- Lack of explicit Duel mode. Instead, there is "1v1 Arena", which really sucks. You have 30 seconds of matchmaking queue in the main menu, followed by 30 seconds of loading and warmup, just to fight one random person in ~5 rounds. As far as I can tell, the matchmaking does little to ensure a fair matchup. So it's 50% waiting and 50% fighting the same person over and over. Whereas Chivalry 1 duel mode was 5% waiting and 95% fighting random people each time.
- There are cheaters. For example, players moving and attacking unnaturally fast. To a Chivalry 1 player, this is shocking, because to the best of my knowledge, Chivalry 1 had no cheaters. I've never even heard of cheaters existing in Chivalry 1 in 1200 hours of gameplay. On the other hand, in Chivalry 2, I've seen at least one blatant cheater myself and players accusing each other of cheating constantly. Not an hour goes by without someone calling cheats with all seriousness. So it's a staggering difference between cheating being non-existent in Chivalry 1, and between cheating infesting Chivalry 2 quite severely.
- Lack of map variety. ~10 hours are enough to learn all the maps. It's mostly the same 5-10 maps over and over. It'll feel repetitive way too early. I don't quite think I should feel like I've seen everything after 25 hours of gameplay - that's not a very good sign.
- Atrocious map balance for Team Objective mode. This manifests itself by a particular objective having very predictable outcome. E.g. in Darkforest, Masons typically do all objectives except the last one, resulting in Agatha victory. Almost always. Takes you 2-3 playthroughs to notice and understand why. I really don't think this was so bad in Chivalry 1.
- Some lack of technical polish here and there. For example, I managed to clip through the floor twice in 25 hours of gameplay. This never happened to me in 1200 hours of Chivalry 1.

Obviously, there are good things too. Together with all the new features that you surely already know about, what I like the most is the much better handled lore and atmosphere. The game world is more fleshed out and it all feels more plausible, though it still has lots of room for improvement in that aspect.

It's not exactly fair to review the game purely from the lens of a Chivalry 1 player, but it's hard to forgive seeing the game struggle at aspects that were already handled well in Chivalry 1. For the sake of remaining open-minded about that, my review verdict is positive.

I bear the Jerusalem Cross and ride my war horse into battle as I bear witness to a crusade for the Lord.

Chivalry 2 is the only game where I can go from feeling like a heroic knight to a complete medieval clown in about three seconds. I’ll land a beautifully timed parry, follow it up with a flawless counter… and then get instantly deleted by some guy named “Sir Loin of Beef” throwing a wagon wheel at my face.

Combat is surprisingly deep, which is wild considering half the time I’m just panic-swinging like I’m trying to swat a bee. But when things click, it feels amazing. Winning a duel in Chivalry 2 is like solving a complex math problem—except instead of being praised, you get screamed at in five different accents.

The real entertainment is the chaos. You’ll see a majestic knight riding into battle, sword raised high… only to trip over a rock and get dog-piled by peasants. I once watched a teammate charge into battle holding nothing but a fish. He got three kills. I don’t understand this game and I don’t think I want to.

Matches feel like 50% skill, 30% luck, and 20% screaming. The voice lines alone are worth the price. If you’re not yelling “FOR THE KING!” while sprinting directly into your own team’s catapult shot, you’re not playing correctly.

Performance is good, the maps are fun, and the chaos is unforgettable. It’s messy, it’s loud, it’s stupid—in the best possible way.

At the end of the day, Chivalry 2 will no longer receive updates or support. We have to assume that what we're seeing now is a blip on a downward trajectory. If no improvements are going to be made, then with each day passing from this review I strongly encourage a skip. 

A list of a bunch of cons:
- Game is 8 dollars frequently, DO NOT BUY FOR FULL PRICE. IT IS ON SALE FOR 80% OFF REGULARLY
- Playerbase is constantly declining, now at the lowest its ever been. Leads to high ping and long queues for players in regions that the game is already dead in.
- Hacking problem is getting worse every day and there are zero plans to address it. If you see a hacker they are almost never going to be banned so assume you will see them until they get bored
- Community has a lot of really racist people. Several of the biggest clans in the game have a long history of it, one of the biggest clans has a slur in their name and constantly uses them.
- If you start now you're essentially cannon fodder. Your skill gap between you and a person who has played since release is so huge that you will not be able to tell if they're cheating or just better. This sucks, because there are a LOT of cheaters.
- Game will no longer receive updates. Game will no longer receive support. If you buy this, assume it will only be playable for another year or two.
- Ping can make this game entirely unplayable. If you're above 100 ping when playing other games I'd autoskip this. 
- REPEAT - DO NOT BUY FOR FULL PRICE. IT IS ON SALE FOR 80% OFF REGULARLY

I have prob 100+ hours on Epic, and I do love the game. I downvote because the devs here are wildly incompetent and while the core gameplay is great, the devs have just done so many stupid things and failed to fix issues before moving on that I can't honestly recommend it.

1) Took the devs well over a year to add horses (something they promised at launch), and when they did, they were so terribly implemented that in order to get them to work they had to *lower the player count on the server to make room for the horses.* No I'm not kidding. Not to mention they are utterly terrible to play with and nobody cares about them or bothers to play on the maps with them.

2) Devs wanted to fix crummy animation exploits: then didn't fix them. Dueling was great for a time, but people have gone back to all the same nonsense in Chivarly 1. Rainbow swings, 360 feints, toe jabs. Not fun. Visually repulsive. Low skill. Devs didn't address any of it and the duel scene suffered for it. Not to mention they never even bothered to add actual duel servers, so every FFA "duel" server is reliant on honor system. Better cross your fingers there's no griefers!

3) Archers have never been fun or interesting for this game. Javelins? Fair enough. But being involved in a heart-pounding, chaotic melee, only to get randomly insta-killed by an archer from 100m away with 0 counter play besides "don't get shot by the guys randomly firing arrows in the crowd" is not just anti-fun but outright cancerous. And no, not "skill issue." I played competitively in Chiv 1 and with/against the best players in the Chiv 2 scene.

4) Game suffered and still suffers from one of the worst and most buggy party systems I've ever seen. It was quite literally non-functional for the better part of a year, and even recently I had difficulty staying in a party after leaving a match. It's honestly baffling how it's been so long and they can't even get their party system to not have failures when doing basic functions.

5) The devs wasted a year implementing horses that nobody cared about, but no worries, because they doubled down by also wasting a ton of development time adding a 3rd faction that nobody cared about, which came with a whole 2 weapons that i can remember, neither of which was viable or interesting to use. In reality, all this meant was new voice lines and cosmetics, while the gameplay remained totally identical, except instead of Team Red vs Team Blue, sometimes you get to fight Team Yellow which plays exactly like the other two teams. The new maps were also bogged down on release by the devs adding in the pointless horses, which lowered the server counts and just made them worse overall.

All-in-all, I actually do think the core melee combat here (when not being heavily exploited), is fantastic, and the chaotic melee brawling is some of the best you can experience in an online game. If only the devs hadn't been so awful. It's fine though, because they've moved on from Chiv to make No More Room in Hell 2, another game with great core gameplay, bogged down by weird design choices, lack of content, and terrible systems that do nothing but subtract from the fun of the core gameplay, just like this game!

These are not good circumstances. The developers have essentially abandoned this game for the better part of a year now to focus on another project. The reporting system, which previously was one of the most effective I've seen, was through Discord, and now those reports are re-directed to the website. The reports sent through the website are then canned messages instructing you to use the in-game reporting mechanism.

Needless to say, nothing happens anymore. Why is this an issue?

Because hacks for this game became easily available and hackers have come through in waves and terrorized the game. Some use it to cheat, some to grief, and recently, some use it to crash the already inconsistent servers. There's no one to bring this up with anymore, and the in-game reporting is impossible to use when a user joins and immediately crashes the server before anyone can do anything about it.

They still sell this game at full price, and while us regulars play around with it and enjoy the game, I cannot fathom newer players paying full price for an online game that doesn't function because the developers have abandoned it.
